Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved rock art on a boulder, showing the figures of one human, two ostriches, an antelope, a cow, a Barbary sheep and two unidentified shapes, all upright and facing left, but for the human figure and Barbary sheep on the left, which face right. The ostriches are infilled, with well-defined edges and pecked and rubbed infill. They stand in the centre of the image, the smaller to the right of the larger. To the right of this is the figure of a quadruped with a long, tapered horn sweeping back (scimitar- horned oryx?). The human figure has arms outstretched sideways and the pecked Barbary sheep appears as if leaping from the human figure’s left arm. To the upper right are two long pecked, infilled legs of an unidentified animal cut off the edge of the image at the joint. Below the antelope figure on the right is an unidentified pecked infilled shape. A 5cm scale has been fitted at the bottom of the image. Wadi Hamra, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Wadi Hamra is a canyon-like valley with a relatively flat floor between one and 200m wide, curling more or less south into the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s Western Desert. There are three known rock art sites, all for engravings and first reported by Has Rhotert in 1952: The first is an old river terrace with numerous engravings of giraffe and a few of ostrich, cattle and abstract fan-shaped grooves, with stone circles and shallow depressions on the top. The second is several engravings further southwest. The third stands opposite the branch containing the first site: a rocky outcrop about 15 m high with a number of engravings along the base.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
